newsitem.title: USA: 401K investors left stock funds in July.
newsitem.headline: 401K investors left stock funds in July.

text.p: Retirement-plan investors abandoned stock mutual funds during an especially turbulent period in July during the market correction, according to a study of 401k plans.
The data defies the traditional view that individuals who put pension money into mutual funds are passive investors.
"Individuals are more likely to move as the market moves," said Stacy Schaus of Hewitt Associates, a Lincolnshire, Ill. human resources consultant. "You might even classify those people as traders."

Hewitt, which conducted the study, found investors pulled about $54.8 million from equity mutual funds between July 11 and July 16. During that time, about $63.2 million flooded into stable-return funds, the study found. The difference between the two sums went into other funds.
The biggest single-day retreat from stock funds, about $25.5 million, occurred on July 16, the day after the Dow Industrials fell 161 points to 5,350., and the Nasdaq Composite fell 43 to 1,060.

The biggest one-day outflow from stable-return funds was $25.2 million on July 17, also marking the biggest one-day gain for stocks funds, about $17.2 million. On July 17, the Dow gained 18 points, and Nasdaq rose 33 points.

"It would indicate that you have a percentage of the population that is doing precisely what they shouldn't be doing," said Schaus. "They are running away when the market drops and coming back in when it goes up."
The survey covered 25 plans with total assets of $21 billion, according to Hewitt.
Analysts said they were looking closely at the survey because to date there has been little data to measure the way 401k investors behave.

"It's surprising to me," said Glen Casey, a defined-contribution consultant at Cerulli Associates in Boston. "It bucks the conventional wisdom that 401k money is less emotional about the market than general retail fund money."
Kent Novell, vice president of Access Research in Windsor, Conn., believes that 401k investors remain less aggressive in moving around fund money than in the past.

"My guess is that in the old 401k world, you would have had much more movement if the market corrected because you knew you could only move your money once a quarter," he said. "Today, when you can move it anytime, there's the tendency to wait it out."
About $675 billion of pension funds were invested in all U.S. mutual funds at the end of 1995, or about 38 percent of $5 trillion in all U.S. retirement funds, according to Access Research.
